questions.question: In the A.N.C.H.O.R. Method™ framework, what is the primary purpose of the 'Assess & Align' phase?
options: To diagnose the child with a specific clinical condition using DSM-5 criteria.
To map the neurodevelopmental profile and align family goals with core values.
To navigate the legal system and secure immediate IEP services.
To implement behavioral modification strategies for immediate compliance.
questions.explanation: The 'Assess & Align' phase focuses on understanding the child's unique neurodevelopmental profile and ensuring that the intervention goals are deeply rooted in the family's specific values.

questions.question: When mapping a neurodevelopmental profile, which 'Big Three' executive functions are most critical to evaluate according to the module content?
options: Reading fluency, mathematical logic, and rote memorization.
Gross motor skills, fine motor skills, and hand-eye coordination.
Working memory, inhibitory control, and cognitive flexibility.
Auditory processing, visual tracking, and tactile sensitivity.
questions.explanation: Working memory, inhibitory control, and cognitive flexibility are the core pillars of executive function that dictate a child's ability to regulate behavior and solve problems.

questions.question: A coach is helping a family set a 'Value-Based Goal.' Which of the following goals best exemplifies this approach?
options: The child will sit still for 20 minutes during dinner without getting up.
The child will reduce self-stimulatory behaviors by 50% within three weeks.
The family will enjoy a 15-minute shared activity that fosters connection and joy.
The child will master 10 new sight words to meet grade-level expectations.
questions.explanation: Value-based goals focus on quality of life, connection, and family harmony rather than just clinical compliance or academic benchmarks.

questions.question: In building a multidisciplinary team (L4), which professional is specifically trained to address 'Sensory Processing' and 'Activities of Daily Living' (ADLs)?
options: Board Certified Behavior Analyst (BCBA)
Speech-Language Pathologist (SLP)
Occupational Therapist (OT)
Educational Consultant
questions.explanation: Occupational Therapists specialize in sensory integration and helping children develop the skills needed for daily functional living.

questions.question: Under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA), what does the 'Least Restrictive Environment' (LRE) mandate?
options: Children with disabilities must be educated in a specialized private school.
Children with disabilities should be educated with non-disabled peers to the maximum extent appropriate.
Children must always be in a general education classroom regardless of their needs.
Schools are required to provide the 'best possible' education regardless of cost.
questions.explanation: LRE requires that students with disabilities receive their education alongside peers without disabilities unless the nature of the disability prevents successful education even with supplementary aids.

questions.question: According to Polyvagal Theory (L6), which state of the nervous system is associated with the 'Social Engagement System' and optimal learning?
options: Sympathetic Nervous System (Fight/Flight)
Dorsal Vagal Complex (Freeze/Shutdown)
Ventral Vagal Complex (Safe/Social)
The HPA Axis (Chronic Stress Response)
questions.explanation: The Ventral Vagal state is the 'green zone' where the heart rate is regulated, and the child feels safe enough to connect and learn.

questions.question: In the 'Rupture and Repair' strategy (L7), what is the first step a parent must take after a conflict occurs?
options: Immediately demand an apology from the child.
Explain to the child why their behavior was unacceptable.
Regulate their own nervous system before attempting to connect.
Remove all privileges to ensure the behavior doesn't happen again.
questions.explanation: Effective repair cannot happen if the caregiver is still in a dysregulated state; self-regulation is the prerequisite for co-regulation.

questions.question: Research on 'Allostatic Load' in special needs caregivers (L8) indicates that chronic stress can lead to which physiological outcome?
options: Increased neuroplasticity and faster cognitive processing.
A 40% reduction in cortisol production over time.
Telomere shortening and accelerated cellular aging.
Heightened immune system response and lower infection rates.
questions.explanation: Chronic caregiving stress is linked to telomere shortening, which is a biological marker of accelerated aging and increased health vulnerability.

questions.question: Case Study: A school tells a parent, 'We don't offer 1-on-1 aides at this school.' Which legal protection should the parent invoke?
options: The Right to Prior Written Notice (PWN)
The Right to Immediate Mediation
The Right to a 504 Plan instead of an IEP
The Right to Change Schools immediately
questions.explanation: Prior Written Notice (PWN) requires the school to provide a written explanation of why they are refusing a specific service requested by the parent.

questions.question: What is the key difference between 'Self-Care' and 'Nervous System Regulation' as taught in Module 15?
options: Self-care is for the child; regulation is for the parent.
Self-care is a luxury; regulation is a clinical requirement.
Self-care is often an occasional activity (e.g., a bath); regulation is a moment-to-moment management of physiological state.
There is no difference; the terms are used interchangeably in the A.N.C.H.O.R. Method™.
questions.explanation: While self-care is important for long-term health, nervous system regulation involves the active, ongoing management of one's internal state to stay present and resilient.
